conversation.input: The I L's speaking test is in total 11 to 14 minutes long. It consists of three parts. The first part is 4 to 5 minutes long. This part is a short interview with personal questions about things such as where you live or what you study after. This part 2 is the part known as the long term. Here you need to speak on your own for two minutes on the subject the examiner will give you. The final part, part 3, is a longer discussion which is linked to the subject. In part 2. These questions are more complex in nature and will promote a more in depth discussion. In part one, you just need to give personal information. The questions may seem quite easy, but try to extend your answers if you can. In Part 2, the examiner will give you a prompt with a topic and four points relating to it. You'll have one minute to prepare and make notes. The examiner will tell you when to start speaking. In part two, you have to speak on your own without any interaction from the examiner, as you'll need to ideally be talking for about minutes. Think about answering all parts of the prompt and connecting your ideas clearly. Don't worry about the timing, the examiner will tell you when to stop speaking and may ask you a follow on question or two. In Part 3, the examiner is looking for more complex language. You should be expressing your views on subjects here. Candidates are marked in four categories, fluency and coherence, lexical resource, grammatical resource, and lastly, pronunciation. conversation.input: The I L's speaking test is in total 11 to 14 minutes long. It consists of three parts. The first part is 4 to 5 minutes long. This part is a short interview with personal questions about things such as where you live or what you study after. This part 2 is the part known as the long term. Here you need to speak on your own for two minutes on the subject the examiner will give you. The final part, part 3, is a longer discussion which is linked to the subject. In part 2. These questions are more complex in nature and will promote a more in depth discussion. In part one, you just need to give personal information. The questions may seem quite easy, but try to extend your answers if you can. In Part 2, the examiner will give you a prompt with a topic and four points relating to it. You'll have one minute to prepare and make notes. The examiner will tell you when to start speaking. In part two, you have to speak on your own without any interaction from the examiner, as you'll need to ideally be talking for about minutes. Think about answering all parts of the prompt and connecting your ideas clearly. Don't worry about the timing, the examiner will tell you when to stop speaking and may ask you a follow on question or two. In Part 3, the examiner is looking for more complex language. You should be expressing your views on subjects here. Candidates are marked in four categories, fluency and coherence, lexical resource, grammatical resource, and lastly, pronunciation. A Band 7 student can speak at length without much effort, can use less common vocabulary and collocations, and paraphrase well, has generally accurate grammar, and uses a range of complex patterns and is easy to understand. conversation.input: Let's move on to talk about travelling. What form of transport do you use most often?

conversation.input: Is there any type of transport that you don't like?
conversation.output: I'm not fond of flying or of traveling on a ship. Being on a plane makes me feel quite anxious, actually. When you take off and land, and I have only been on a shape once, but I got quite seasick.

conversation.input: What's the public transport system like in your country?
conversation.output: In my city it's very good, the buses are reliable and the trains always run on time. People don't mind leaving their cars at home, to go to work at the service is really good.

conversation.output: I think they should create more cycle lines. More people would probably travel to work or to their college or university if the roads were safer for cyclists at the moment. If you ride a bike, you have to share the road with cars and lorries, which isn't, very nice.

conversation.input: That sounds great. Now, would you say that the majority of cities in your country are overcrowded?

And, you know, the streets in India are, they're very narrow and people keep building illegal shops and houses, which makes the area even more congested And due to improper enforcement of traffic laws, people bike, their people park their bikes and cars everywhere they want to. So I think it just increases the problem.

conversation.input: Then what are some problems that can result from overcrowded liver conditions in a typical metropolitan city .

I think it results in greater level of pollution, both the noise and the air, obviously there will be more motor vehicles which will result in more polluted air and more traffic noise because the traffic grows in our city. And another problem would be, I think, disease vulnerability, as during the time of Covid, I saw that it was so hard to maintain social distancing, especially in the markets if you're in India because of the enormous crowd everywhere and then there are other reasons. Lack of space also has a direct effect on your psychological and your physical growth as well. And then the, you know, exploitation of resources leads to inflation, and then there's lack of access to services like clean drinking water or sanitation, which leads to more diseases, increased disease rate in India. And I think the crime rate increases as well.

conversation.input: So in your opinion, what are some solutions to this problem?

These cities should provide better and safer housing for the people, as nearly 50% of the Mumbai's population lives in slums. I mean, they provide great plot for the feel, sorry for the poor and lovely wretches for the liberal writing, but nobody tries to improve the situation or provide a solution for it. The grave consequences of overpopulation needs to be addressed by the government. The government should take steps to regulate the crowd somehow, to disperse the population, even the roads. They're so narrow, and even when they try to build flyovers, a project like that takes at least 4 to five years to get over in India. And during that time, your population doubles, and then you need another fly over. And I think it's important to control the flow of people. And for that, you first need to understand where the flow is coming from. And I think in short term solutions, like during festivals, we celebrate many festivals throughout the year. So if you have proper planning on how to disperse crowd, you can award that .

Even today, I go back to her for all the problems that I come across with, be it in my professional life or my personal life, that one person is just one phone call away for me. Okay.

conversation.input: thank you. Can I have the paper and pencil back, please, sure. Thank you. Okay, so let's discuss leisure and activities in your country. What types of leisure activities are popular in your home country?
conversation.output: We have all sort of leisure activities, right? From hanging around with friends at parks, picnics, going out for a movie in theaters, to some place like a Broadway theater or something like that. So we enjoy doing all sorts of sort of activities.

conversation.input: What sort of theater and, do people in your country prefer?
conversation.output: We have a lot of strong theater, which need not be a Broadway kind of a theater, but it's more like a play. Some of them being like we theater wherein we showcase a lot of plays and there are a lot of people who love being part of theater groups.

conversation.input: Why is it important for people to have time for leisure activities?
conversation.output: I think that is one time of the day or for one time in a week wherein you just get to unwind yourself, not worry about the daily tours, the tension that you have at work or at family. You can just be yourself, let loose, and let the inner kid in you be out for some time.

conversation.input: Do you think that's important?
conversation.output: Yes, okay.

conversation.input: The same as when your parents were young.
conversation.output: No, a lot of things have changed. Maybe during our parents are bringing the leisure activity for them would be just going out for a theater to watch a movie or a play as opposed to today where there are a lot of other social joints which are readily available like some bars, sports bars, or even a lot of mall culture for, you know, people go out to the mall, just hang out there, which are not the thing back there.

conversation.input: Why do you think this has changed?
conversation.output: Part reason that I think it has changed is because we are now more aware of what's happening around the globe which was not the case in the past. So there's a lot of Western influence in the country right now. So it's like the cool thing these days to do, visit malls, multiplexes. So that's like a cool thing these days.

conversation.input: So finally, let's discuss sports, sports in your country. So which sports are popular in your home country?
conversation.output: Like I said, cricket is the most popular sport back in a in my country.

conversation.input: Are there any other sports that are popular?
conversation.output: Hockey, tennis, recently, badminton. That's because some people are doing good at the global level and that's why people are watching it more often now.

conversation.input: And what are the benefits supply applying sports?
conversation.output: Ports I think is very important right from the childhood because that's the physical activity as, as they say, is the most important part of your upbringing. So there are two things, mental strength and physical development, which you get only via sports.

conversation.input: So do many parents have their children practice sports?
conversation.output: Yes, there are a lot of clubs that students get into, even in the schools we have like a mandatory subject of sports.

conversation.input: Well, this types of sports that are popular now change in the future.
conversation.output: I see to some extent, definitely crickets not going anywhere for sure. It's been there for the last couple of decades and I don't see it changing. But yeah, a lot of people are these days interested in following the European League, so that might change a little bit, but not not to watch it.

conversation.input: And how can sports bring people from different countries and backgrounds closer together?
conversation.output: I think Olympics would be the best example for that. So that's one place where people from all the countries, all the underdogs can just come in and showcase. That's one place where they can all come together and not discuss about the political agenda, but, you know, try to show how we all are doing unitedly in a common sport.

conversation.input: And which hobbies and interests do you enjoy?

conversation.input: And do you think parents should encourage their children to have a hobby or interest?
conversation.output: Oh, yes, very much. I think it is very important for children to have something other than school television and computers. Sometimes a hobby can turn into a very successful career, but even if it doesn't, it can help the child develop as a person as they learn about new things and meet new people who share the same hobby.

conversation.input: Now let's move on to talk about the weather. Do you prefer hot weather or cold?
conversation.output: I think I prefer gold weather. I know most people prefer hot weather, but it is always so hot in my country that it is such a nice change to feel the gold. Of course, in the gold it's very easy to put on a hat and gloves to keep ourselves warm.

conversation.input: Tell me about the weather in your country at different times of year.
conversation.output: India is so big that there are many different climates, so I'll just talk about the weather in Hyderabad. Generally we have a tropical, wet and dry climate. That means that the summers, march to June, a hot over 30 degrees and very humid. Sometimes it can reach over 40, which is just unbearable. At the end of the summer, the monsoon comes and it rains for about three months after the rainy season. It's winter, which is quite short, just a couple of months.

conversation.input: Which time of year did you enjoy most as a child?
conversation.output: Well, I think like most children, I would say the summer when we had the long school holiday, but I always preferred spring. There's something so lovely about when everything starts to grow again after the winter, you can almost smell it in the air.

conversation.input: And has the weather changed much in your country in recent years?
conversation.output: I don't think so, really. I know that in some countries the climate has been changing because of global warming, but where I live, it seems to be the same, just heat and rain.

conversation.input: I have noticed something .
conversation.output: in recent summers when it's very hot, there have been many water shortages, I don't remember that happening when I was younger.

We had a few days holiday from work and we decided to fulfill my husband's dream. As I said earlier I'm really interested in art and so even though I had no real desire to go to Islam, I was totally captivated by all the beautiful buildings and the wonderful arts and crafts that were available there. The Blue Mosque was my favorite building. From the outside it looks just like a typical Ottoman mosque, but inside it is quite startling. The large windows with the light reflecting on the exquisite blue tiles made it just breathtaking. I asked one of the guides, about the tiles and she told me that they were from and that they are still made today. When we left the Blue Mosque, we walked down a pedestrian lane full of shops, including some in one of the shops, the owner told us that the tiles were made in ethnic. Anyway, one of the tiles really caught my eye actually it sang to me, it was of fish, 4 big fish and lots of little ones, all in different shades of green. I really, really, really wanted it, but when we asked the price, it was very high, something like 300 American dollars. Obviously I knew we could negotiate, but it seemed such a high price that we just left the next night we went out for my birthday meal just as we were finisheding the dessert, the waiter came over and handed me the most beautifully wrapped gift I knew at once, because it was very heavy, that it was the fish style. That's why I.

conversation.input: And does this person often, often buy your presence?
conversation.output: Well, he's good at remembering my birthday and our anniversary. So he does usually buy me something nice then. But he doesn't just buy a present out of the blue.

conversation.input: Thank you. Could I have the booklet, the pencil on the paper back, please? I'm cute. Now you've been telling me about a present you received, and I'd like to ask you some more general questions related to this. So let's talk about attitudes to gifts. Can you tell me something about how people feel when they receive a homemade gift and when they receive a shop bought gift? Now you've been telling me about a present you received, and I'd like to ask you some more general questions related to this. So let's talk about attitudes to gifts. Can you tell me something about how people feel when they receive a homemade gift and when they receive a shop bought gift?
conversation.output: Well, I think, as with everything, it depends on the person and the gift. When a grandchild makes something for their grandparents, like a bookmark or a playpot that they've made at school, then obviously their grandparents will treasure it. For adults, I think it's a bit different. If people are going to give homemade gifts, then they need to be of really good quality.

conversation.input: Why do you say that?
conversation.output: Well, when children make things, it's the thought that counts. But when it's adults making things, it has to look like the present is a proper present rather than something they've made just because it's cheaper. Of course, the thought still counts, and in many ways, our time now is more important or precious than than money. So if somebody has spent a lot of time making a gift, it will mean a lot. But if someone has made some chutneys or pickles or some of the type of food, then it has to be edible and taste nice as well.

conversation.input: So what about shopboard gifts?
conversation.output: Most gifts these days are shopboard, and there isn't really anything wrong with that. What is important, I think, with a shopboard gift is that the person buying the gift should spend some time thinking about what the other person would really appreciate. It's no good husband going into a perfume shop and buying the first perfume he likes. He needs to see what perfume his wife is wearing that shows his wife that he's paying her attention.

conversation.input: And do you think that children get more pleasure receiving gifts than adults do?
conversation.output: Yes and no. Obviously, children love receiving gifts, but children do generally get a lot of gifts. Children these days are spoilt and they get too many gifts, so the more gifts they get, the less they value them. Adults, on the other hand, generally have the resources to buy things for themselves, so if they really want something, they can buy it. Of course, this then makes present buying for adults much more difficult. But of course, there are things that we like that we can't really afford, or we can afford them but can't justify their expense.

conversation.input: What sort of things are you thinking of .
conversation.output: for women? It might be perfume or a day at the spa, or a new pair of party heels for men, usually something to do with their hobbies or books or CDS.

conversation.input: Do you think that more people get more pleasure giving or receiving gifts?
conversation.output: Oh, this is a tricky one, why? Well, I think most people get pleasure out of both, of course it depends, we may not get a lot of pleasure out of giving gifts to children who we know may not appreciate them. But, if we have found the perfect gift for someone we love and we know it's going to make them happy, well then this will really fill our hearts with joy. Similarly, if someone receives a gift of something that they don't really want or they consent that it has been bought out of haste, then this isn't really going to make them feel that good. But if it's something wonderful, then, well, of course they're going to feel fantastic about it.

conversation.input: Let's move on to talk about the commercial aspects of giving. How much do advertisements influence people when they buy gifts?
conversation.output: In my opinion, probably not too much. I mean, most adverts are for things like cars and household products, which aren't really gifts, although a lot of young people like to be given new phones and other gadgets. So if a parent isn't sure which model to get, then they could be influenced by advertising.

conversation.input: And do you think that some festivals have become commercialized as a result of the emphasis on buying gift?
conversation.output: Oh, yes, definitely, yes. In fact, I think it's much worse than that. It's not just the old festivals becoming commercialized, but so called new ones being created just for the sake of present giving.

conversation.input: Can you tell me more about that?
conversation.output: Yes, things like Vale Valentine's Day and Mother's Day, these aren't interim traditions, but suddenly we find we have to buy a present for our spouse on Valentine's Day. And while it is nice to recognize how important our mothers are, surely it should be something we do every day, not just once a year when we buy her some chocolates.

conversation.input: Thank you very much Sabah, that is the end of the speaking test.

Now you've been telling me about a present you received, and I'd like to ask you some more general questions related to this. So let's talk about attitudes to gifts. Can you tell me something about how people feel when they receive a homemade gift and when they receive a shop bought gift?
conversation.output: Well, I think, as with everything, it depends on the person and the gift. When a grandchild makes something for their grandparents, like a bookmark or a playpot that they've made at school, then obviously their grandparents will treasure it. For adults, I think it's a bit different. If people are going to give homemade gifts, then they need to be of really good quality.

conversation.input: Why do you say that?
conversation.output: Well, when children make things, it's the thought that counts. But when it's adults making things, it has to look like the present is a proper present rather than something they've made just because it's cheaper. Of course, the thought still counts, and in many ways, our time now is more important or precious than than money. So if somebody has spent a lot of time making a gift, it will mean a lot. But if someone has made some chutneys or pickles or some of the type of food, then it has to be edible and taste nice as well.

conversation.input: So what about shopboard gifts?
conversation.output: Most gifts these days are shopboard, and there isn't really anything wrong with that. What is important, I think, with a shopboard gift is that the person buying the gift should spend some time thinking about what the other person would really appreciate. It's no good husband going into a perfume shop and buying the first perfume he likes. He needs to see what perfume his wife is wearing that shows his wife that he's paying her attention.

conversation.input: And do you think that children get more pleasure receiving gifts than adults do?
conversation.output: Yes and no. Obviously, children love receiving gifts, but children do generally get a lot of gifts. Children these days are spoilt and they get too many gifts, so the more gifts they get, the less they value them. Adults, on the other hand, generally have the resources to buy things for themselves, so if they really want something, they can buy it. Of course, this then makes present buying for adults much more difficult. But of course, there are things that we like that we can't really afford, or we can afford them but can't justify their expense.

conversation.input: What sort of things are you thinking of .
conversation.output: for women? It might be perfume or a day at the spa, or a new pair of party heels for men, usually something to do with their hobbies or books or CDS.

conversation.input: Do you think that more people get more pleasure giving or receiving gifts?
conversation.output: Oh, this is a tricky one, why? Well, I think most people get pleasure out of both, of course it depends, we may not get a lot of pleasure out of giving gifts to children who we know may not appreciate them. But, if we have found the perfect gift for someone we love and we know it's going to make them happy, well then this will really fill our hearts with joy. Similarly, if someone receives a gift of something that they don't really want or they consent that it has been bought out of haste, then this isn't really going to make them feel that good. But if it's something wonderful, then, well, of course they're going to feel fantastic about it.

conversation.input: Let's move on to talk about the commercial aspects of giving. How much do advertisements influence people when they buy gifts?
conversation.output: In my opinion, probably not too much. I mean, most adverts are for things like cars and household products, which aren't really gifts, although a lot of young people like to be given new phones and other gadgets. So if a parent isn't sure which model to get, then they could be influenced by advertising.

conversation.input: And do you think that some festivals have become commercialized as a result of the emphasis on buying gift?
conversation.output: Oh, yes, definitely, yes. In fact, I think it's much worse than that. It's not just the old festivals becoming commercialized, but so called new ones being created just for the sake of present giving.

conversation.input: Can you tell me more about that?
conversation.output: Yes, things like Vale Valentine's Day and Mother's Day, these aren't interim traditions, but suddenly we find we have to buy a present for our spouse on Valentine's Day. And while it is nice to recognize how important our mothers are, surely it should be something we do every day, not just once a year when we buy her some chocolates.

conversation.input: Where would you go to buy flowers?
conversation.output: I could go to several places like the supermarket or the open end market near my house. However, if they are to be given to somebody special, I would go to a florist because they have a large variety and they make nice arrangements with them.

conversation.input: On what occasions would you give someone flowers?
conversation.output: Personally, I give flowers to my mother on Mother's Day and my best friend on her birthday. I don't give flowers on any other occasion. But sometimes people bring flowers for you if they are invited to dinner. Valentine's Way is a time when people give flowers too.

conversation.input: Oh, okay, now let's move on to the third part of the speaking test, we've been talking about the subject of visitors. I'd like to discuss this subject with you with some more general questions relating to this topic. First, tell me, how do people treat visitors in your country?
conversation.output: To begin with, I believe people in my country are very hospitable when a visitor come to their house, they welcome them warmly and treat them politely and with respect as soon as they arrive. They also offer them a drink of tea or coffee and some kind of sweets. They might have also prepared a meal or they will order a takeaway depending on the situation and occasion. Generally speaking, the people of my country are very warm in kind hose.

conversation.input: What are the benefits of staying with a friend when you visit a new place?
conversation.output: The first thing that springs my mind is that it is less expensive. The reason for this is that you don't have to pay for accommodation and you can prepare some meals at home, which is cheaper than eating out. Another thing is that you don't feel lonely out of rate in a strange place and your friends will always be there with you. Also, if you want to do some sightseeing, you won't need maps or guides because your friends can show you around and tell you where to go.

conversation.input: Then what are the advantages of staying in a hotel instead?
conversation.output: One of the obvious advantages is that a hotel offers great facilities. This could be a swimming pool, a cafeteria, or a tennis court, for example. The rooms are heated or air conditioned and you don't have to clean up or make your own bed, so it is more comfortable and relaxing. Also, there is room service where you can order anything like means and also you get a lot of privacy.

conversation.input: Do you think hospitality is more or less important than it was in the past?
conversation.output: That's an interesting question. In my view, hospitality today is just as important as it was in the past. What I mean is that when you visit somebody's house, you want them to welcome you warmly and make you feel special. And if they don't, then you won't have a good time and you might not go back again. The same applies with hospitality in a new country. If you are hospitable, tourists will return in the future and this will benefit your country. This is what applied in the past and the still applies now as far as I'm concerned.

conversation.input: Okay, now moving on to talk about benefits of traveling abroad. What do you think people can learn from traveling to other countries?
conversation.output: They can learn numerous things. As travelling broadens the mind. They can experience different cultures and learn about other people's custom and traditions. Also, they can learn about their music and lifestyle. Another thing is that they can learn about their traditional cuisine and about the way they think and behave.

conversation.input: Do you think traveling to another country can change the way people think?
conversation.output: Yes, I believe so. When you visit a new country and actually experience how those people live, see what their needs are, learn how they think and believe, only then will you be fully aware of certain things about them that you had not realized before. This will help you overcome any prejudices that you may have had and become less than a minded. Without doubt, traveling abroad helps break down national barriers and contributes to international understanding between nations.

conversation.input: Do you think a community can benefit if some of the people who live there have experienced traveling to other countries?
conversation.output: It definitely can be a benefit. Those people who have traveled abroad would most likely to have been exposed to different ways, ideas, or systems.

conversation.input: Okay, can you elaborate a little more on this?
conversation.output: Sure, I mean, if they have seen or learned something positive, something that works in a better way, for instance, and try to implement it in their community would be beneficial for everyone. Also, I believe that these people would be more open to new ideas and would influence the other members of the community to accept progressive progress of changes.

conversation.input: That's wonderful. And we are at the end of this speaking test. Thank you.
conversation.output: thank you so much.

Generally speaking, the people of my country are very warm in kind hose.

conversation.input: What are the benefits of staying with a friend when you visit a new place?
conversation.output: The first thing that springs my mind is that it is less expensive. The reason for this is that you don't have to pay for accommodation and you can prepare some meals at home, which is cheaper than eating out. Another thing is that you don't feel lonely out of rate in a strange place and your friends will always be there with you. Also, if you want to do some sightseeing, you won't need maps or guides because your friends can show you around and tell you where to go.

conversation.input: Then what are the advantages of staying in a hotel instead?
conversation.output: One of the obvious advantages is that a hotel offers great facilities. This could be a swimming pool, a cafeteria, or a tennis court, for example. The rooms are heated or air conditioned and you don't have to clean up or make your own bed, so it is more comfortable and relaxing. Also, there is room service where you can order anything like means and also you get a lot of privacy.

conversation.input: Do you think hospitality is more or less important than it was in the past?
conversation.output: That's an interesting question. In my view, hospitality today is just as important as it was in the past. What I mean is that when you visit somebody's house, you want them to welcome you warmly and make you feel special. And if they don't, then you won't have a good time and you might not go back again. The same applies with hospitality in a new country. If you are hospitable, tourists will return in the future and this will benefit your country. This is what applied in the past and the still applies now as far as I'm concerned.

conversation.input: Okay, now moving on to talk about benefits of traveling abroad. What do you think people can learn from traveling to other countries?
conversation.output: They can learn numerous things. As travelling broadens the mind. They can experience different cultures and learn about other people's custom and traditions. Also, they can learn about their music and lifestyle. Another thing is that they can learn about their traditional cuisine and about the way they think and behave.

conversation.input: Do you think traveling to another country can change the way people think?
conversation.output: Yes, I believe so. This will help you overcome any prejudices that you may have had and become less than a minded. Without doubt, traveling abroad helps break down national barriers and contributes to international understanding between nations.

conversation.input: Do you think a community can benefit if some of the people who live there have experienced traveling to other countries?
conversation.output: It definitely can be a benefit. Those people who have traveled abroad would most likely to have been exposed to different ways, ideas, or systems.

conversation.input: Okay, can you elaborate a little more on this?

Whether you're looking for an item of furniture for the living room or an ornament or something nice for the garden, I would imagine the shop appeals more to women than men. Certainly when I go there, there are often more women inside looking alone while their husbands or partners stand outside waiting for them to come back out. I think people who like to be surrounded by beautiful things enjoy going there. It's also a great place to go if you want to buy someone a present. If I had the chance, I would buy everything on sale. The thing I like most about the shop is that the things itself are different to what you find in the chain stores. They're handmade and produced by local businesses. And so, you know, you're buying something that nobody else has. Oh, it also sells a lot of things that have been recycled. For example, you'll often find an older cupboard or wardrobe that's been sanded down and painted in lovely patterns that me get look very bright, bright and modern. Yes, that's definitely my favorite show.

conversation.input: We've been talking about the subject of shops and shopping. I'd like to discuss this subject with you with some more general questions relating to this topic. First, do you think people often buy things they don't really need?
conversation.output: Well, I definitely have, it's very easy to fall in love with an item of clothing or a gadget of some kind and then change our mind when we get back home. I think for most people, they have lots of things in their homes that they've bought and never used or used ones and then forgotten about .

conversation.input: what are the advantages of shopping on the high streets rather than online?
conversation.output: For me, the most important thing about the high street is that it's a pretty happening place where you can walk around window shop and actually examine the thing you might wanna buy. Oh, also, if it's a local street, you might bump into friends you haven't seen for a while, and that's always a good thing.

conversation.input: How important is good customer service?
conversation.output: In my opinion, being treated well by shop assistance is really important. For example, I think it's nice to be left alone when you walk into a shop so that you can look around without feeling under pressure to body. If you have a question, it's always good to have someone who's knowledgeable to help you.

conversation.input: Do you think shops should be required to close on certain days?
conversation.output: I know that in the past in my country, shops used to be closed on Sundays. So on the one hand, that was a good thing because it gave everyone a day off to rats and spend time with their families or their loved ones. But on the other hand, days can be quite boring if the shops are closed and you don't have in Wales card.

conversation.input: What are the benefits of going shopping with a friend?
conversation.output: Well, apart from having company, I think one advantage is that your friend can give you their opinion when you buy something. As I mentioned earlier, about buying things that you don't need, perhaps you are less likely to do this if you have a friend or someone with you to make you think before you spend your money on something.

conversation.input: In which ways do adverse persuade us to buy a particular product?
conversation.output: Pirammon I think, they try to make us feel like our lives will be better or that we will be happier if we buy the product. For example, if we drink their brand of coffee, we will be surrounded by friends. Or if we buy this meal for our family, we will all sit around the table laughing and having fun.

conversation.input: This is the speaking test of the international English language testing system. The examiner is Michelle Lester. Good afternoon. Can you tell me your full name, please?
conversation.output: Good afternoon, my name is aramanjit Singh.

conversation.input: And what shall I call you?
conversation.output: You can call me Raman.

conversation.input: Where are you from?
conversation.output: I come from India, originally from the city of Ludhiana. It is located at the north side of the state of Punjab.

conversation.input: All right, so in the first part of the exam I'd like to ask you some questions about yourself. Let's talk about the weather. Tell me about the weather in your country.
conversation.output: In general we have quite a mild climate, but perhaps because of global warming it can get quite hot in the summer. We have also had a lot of flooding in parts of the country, which have also increased in recent years.

conversation.input: What kind of weather do you like best?
conversation.output: Honestly speaking, I don't like extreme weather conditions, Rainy weather or really hot, sunny days don't appeal to me at all. I prefer the weather during autumn, it's not too hot and the days also get longer.

conversation.input: What kind of weather do you like when you go on holiday?
conversation.output: To be honest, we usually spend our holidays walking in the countryside, so I prefer mild weather because it's not very enjoyable walking in heavy rain and not too sunny either, as it's easy to get sunburned if you are outside a lot of the day.

conversation.input: Would you prefer to live in a country with a hot or a cold climate?
conversation.output: Actually, I don't really like extreme weather conditions. The climate is quite mild in my country and it never really gets uncomfortable. I'm really not at all keen on hot weather, so I wouldn't like to live anywhere where it gets sweltering hot.

conversation.input: Let's move on to talk about exercise. Do you like to keep fit?
conversation.output: Yes, I take part in a lot of different sports. I play cricket for my college and go swimming once or twice a week. Having said that I'm not fond of going to the gym. I find that a bit boring.

conversation.input: Which sports are popular in your country?
conversation.output: Cricket probably, it's certainly the one that most people talk about and watch on TV, even if they don't play it. However, other things like gymnastics is also very popular and possibly the activity that most people take part in.

conversation.input: Did you do any sports when you were younger that you don't do now?
conversation.output: I used to play basketball when I was at school, but I wasn't very good at it, and I didn't continue with it when I left. We used to do gymnastics as well, and I enjoyed that, but again, I didn't do that once I finisheded school.

conversation.input: Is there a sport that you like to do you had never done before?
conversation.output: You know, I can't swim, but I would love to learn. I have had lessons in the past, but I found it quite difficult. I'm always disappointed when I go on holidays with my friends and can't join them in the swimming pool or in the sea.

conversation.input: Now moving on to the second part of the test. I'm going to give you a topic, and I'd like you to talk about it for one or two minutes before you talk. You have one minute to think about what you are going to say. You can make some notes if you wish. Do you understand.

Can you start speaking now, please? Remember, you have one or two minutes for this, so don't worry if I stop you. I'll tell you when the time is up. Can you start speaking now, please?
conversation.output: So food plays an important part in my life, so this is a good question. It's really hard to choose just one meal as there are several things I enjoy eating, but if I had to choose 1, it would be a curry. Perhaps one with chicken from restaurant near where I live, We eat a lot of foreign food at home, for example, Chinese, Italian, Mexican, usually my friends and I will take it in turns to cook and we have curry at least once a week. Honestly speaking, our cooking is okay most of the time, but we have a takeaway on Friday evening as a treat. It's always difficult to decide what to have, but I try to persuade them to order Indian food. In the area where I live, there are a lots of Indian restaurants and I have probably tried all of them, but there's one in particular that makes really nice, nice curryries. There are so many different kinds and it depends on your taste, which one you would like best. What makes Indian food special for me is all the spices used. I usually order a hot curry, a dish with the extra chill in it, The first few mouthfuls burn a bit of course, but you slowly get used to the heat. The food is always beautifully cooked and they often give you something free like small side dishes.

conversation.input: We've been talking about the subject of food, and I'd like to discuss this subject with you with some more general questions relating to this topic. First, what is the appeal of eating out in a restaurant?
conversation.output: I think one reason is that others do all the work, cooking the food, serving it, and washing up afterwards. But also it's exciting to eat out, especially if it's a nice restaurant with the high quality food. Food.

conversation.input: What do you think makes a good dinner host?
conversation.output: Well, let me think. I think the host should be able to cook. It wouldn't be a very nice evening if the meal wasn't tasty. I think it's important that a host makes you feel comfortable as well, and they should also be good at keeping the conversations going to encourage everyone to have a good time.

conversation.input: Fast food is often criticised by food experts, so why is it so popular with people?
conversation.output: Probably because it's quick and convenient if you have had a busy day at work or have been studying all day long, you might not want to spend time cooking. In some places you can just drive in order your food, pay and drive home. So it's very easy.

conversation.input: Do you think it's always best to eat food with ingredients that have been produced locally?
conversation.output: You know, I think it's good for the environment, it means food isn't being transported around the country or even around the world, It's obviously also good for the local economy if food is bought from farmers and other food producers in the area.

conversation.input: Is it important to eat together at the dinner table rather than in front of the TV, for example?
conversation.output: My parents always made me and my sister eat at the table at mealtimes. We weren't allowed to have our mobile phones with us when we were eating. So yeah, in my opinion, this was a good idea as it meant we were able to talk to each other and find out what was going on in our lives at the time.

conversation.input: How can we best encourage people to eat a healthy diet?
conversation.output: To be honest, I think you need to start by educating children so that they get into good habits. It's a good idea to encourage them to help prepare food. I think there's more chance they'll eat things they normally wouldn't like if they are involved more in cooking.

conversation.input: That is the end of the speaking test. Thank you.
conversation.output: Thank you.

conversation.input: So what about shopboard gifts?
conversation.output: Most gifts these days are shopboard, and there isn't really anything wrong with that. conversation.input: And do you think parents should encourage their children to have a hobby or interest?

conversation.input: Now let's move on to talk about the weather. Do you prefer hot weather or cold?

conversation.input: Tell me about the weather in your country at different times of year.

That means that the summers, march to June, a hot over 30 degrees and very humid. Sometimes it can reach over 40, which is just unbearable. At the end of the summer, the monsoon comes and it rains for about three months after the rainy season. It's winter, which is quite short, just a couple of months.

conversation.input: Which time of year did you enjoy most as a child?
conversation.output: Well, I think like most children, I would say the summer when we had the long school holiday, but I always preferred spring. There's something so lovely about when everything starts to grow again after the winter, you can almost smell it in the air.

conversation.input: And has the weather changed much in your country in recent years?
conversation.output: I don't think so, really. I know that in some countries the climate has been changing because of global warming, but where I live, it seems to be the same, just heat and rain.

conversation.input: I have noticed something .

Can you tell me something about how people feel when they receive a homemade gift and when they receive a shop bought gift?
conversation.output: Well, I think, as with everything, it depends on the person and the gift. When a grandchild makes something for their grandparents, like a bookmark or a playpot that they've made at school, then obviously their grandparents will treasure it. For adults, I think it's a bit different. If people are going to give homemade gifts, then they need to be of really good quality.

conversation.input: Why do you say that?
conversation.output: Well, when children make things, it's the thought that counts. But when it's adults making things, it has to look like the present is a proper present rather than something they've made just because it's cheaper. Of course, the thought still counts, and in many ways, our time now is more important or precious than than money. So if somebody has spent a lot of time making a gift, it will mean a lot. But if someone has made some chutneys or pickles or some of the type of food, then it has to be edible and taste nice as well.

conversation.input: So what about shopboard gifts?
conversation.output: Most gifts these days are shopboard, and there isn't really anything wrong with that. What is important, I think, with a shopboard gift is that the person buying the gift should spend some time thinking about what the other person would really appreciate. It's no good husband going into a perfume shop and buying the first perfume he likes. He needs to see what perfume his wife is wearing that shows his wife that he's paying her attention.

conversation.input: And do you think that children get more pleasure receiving gifts than adults do?
conversation.output: Yes and no. Obviously, children love receiving gifts, but children do generally get a lot of gifts. Children these days are spoilt and they get too many gifts, so the more gifts they get, the less they value them. Adults, on the other hand, generally have the resources to buy things for themselves, so if they really want something, they can buy it. Of course, this then makes present buying for adults much more difficult. But of course, there are things that we like that we can't really afford, or we can afford them but can't justify their expense.

conversation.input: What sort of things are you thinking of .

conversation.input: Do you think that more people get more pleasure giving or receiving gifts?
conversation.output: Oh, this is a tricky one, why? Well, I think most people get pleasure out of both, of course it depends, we may not get a lot of pleasure out of giving gifts to children who we know may not appreciate them. But, if we have found the perfect gift for someone we love and we know it's going to make them happy, well then this will really fill our hearts with joy. Similarly, if someone receives a gift of something that they don't really want or they consent that it has been bought out of haste, then this isn't really going to make them feel that good. But if it's something wonderful, then, well, of course they're going to feel fantastic about it.

conversation.input: Can you tell me more about that?

So there are a lot of qualities of her that have influenced me right from my childhood, right from being a strong, independent, working woman. She's one person who likes to speak her mind and at the same time, she's compassionate. Those are the qualities of hers that have really influenced me a lot. The reason why that person is very important to me is because she is this one blend of being soft and hard at the same time. So she would just be very nice and kind to us whenever needed. But at times when it was, when it was very important for her to put her food down and make things right for us, she wouldn't think even one step and would be the hard person that was needed to be. She has given me the independence to make choices of my own, live by the choices. And but at the same time, she was that one person who would help my hand and make me aware of the pros and the cons of the choices. If I would go ahead and make those. So that's the reason she is the most important person of my life. Even today, I go back to her for all the problems that I come across with, be it in my professional life or my personal life, that one person is just one phone call away for me. Okay.

conversation.input: thank you. Can I have the paper and pencil back, please, sure. Thank you. Okay, so let's discuss leisure and activities in your country. What types of leisure activities are popular in your home country?
conversation.output: We have all sort of leisure activities, right? From hanging around with friends at parks, picnics, going out for a movie in theaters, to some place like a Broadway theater or something like that. So we enjoy doing all sorts of sort of activities.

conversation.input: What sort of theater and, do people in your country prefer?
conversation.output: We have a lot of strong theater, which need not be a Broadway kind of a theater, but it's more like a play. Some of them being like we theater wherein we showcase a lot of plays and there are a lot of people who love being part of theater groups.

conversation.input: Why is it important for people to have time for leisure activities?
conversation.output: I think that is one time of the day or for one time in a week wherein you just get to unwind yourself, not worry about the daily tours, the tension that you have at work or at family. You can just be yourself, let loose, and let the inner kid in you be out for some time.

conversation.input: Do you think that's important?
conversation.output: Yes, okay.

conversation.input: And are there any other kinds of leisure activities that people do in Mumbai?
conversation.output: Yeah, a lot of people love playing a lot of sport activities like cricket, which is like a national sport of India, they love watching sports, There are a lot of sports bars, a lot of bowling alleys and stuff like that.

conversation.input: Okay, and are there types of leisure activities that are popular in your home country today? The same as when your parents were young?
conversation.output: No, a lot of things have changed, maybe during our parents are bringing the leisure activity for them would be just going out for a theater to watch a movie or a play as opposed to today where there are a lot of other social joints which are readily available, like some bars, sports bars, or even a lot of mall culture for, you know, people go out to the mall, just hang out there, which are not the thing back there.

conversation.input: Why do you think this has changed?
conversation.output: Part reason that I think it has changed is because we are now more aware of what's happening around the globe, which was not the case in the past. So there's a lot of Western influence in the country right now. So it's like the cool thing these days to do, visit malls, multiplexes. So that's like a cool thing these days.

conversation.input: So finally, let's discuss sports. Sports in your country. So which sports are popular in your home country?
conversation.output: Like I said, cricket is the most popular sport back in a, in my country.

conversation.input: Are there any other sports that are popular?
conversation.output: Hockey, tennis, recently, badminton, that's because some people are doing good at the global level and that's why people are watching it more often now.

conversation.input: And what are the benefits supply applying sports.
conversation.output: ports, I think is very important right from the childhood because that's the physical activity as, as they say, is the most important part of your upbringing. So there are two things, mental strength and physical development, which you get only via sports.

conversation.input: So do many parents have their children practice sports?
conversation.output: Yes, there are a lot of clubs that students get into. Even in the schools. We have like a mandatory subject of sports.

conversation.input: Well, this types of sports that are popular now change in the future.
conversation.output: I see to some extent definitely crickets not going anywhere for sure. It's been there for the last couple of decades and I don't see it changing. But yeah, a lot of people are these days interested in following the European League, so that might change a little bit, but not not to watch it.

conversation.input: And how can sports bring people from different countries and backgrounds closer together?
conversation.output: I think Olympics would be the best example for that. So that's one place where people from all the countries, all the underdogs, can just come in and showcase. That's one place where they can all come together and not discuss about the political agenda, but, you know, try to show how we all are doing unitedly in a common sport.

conversation.input: This is the speaking test of the international English language testing system. The examiner is Michelle Lester. Good afternoon. Can you tell me your full name, please?
conversation.output: Good afternoon, my name is aramanjit Singh.

conversation.input: And what shall I call you?
conversation.output: You can call me Raman.

conversation.input: Where are you from?
conversation.output: I come from India, originally from the city of Ludhiana. It is located at the north side of the state of Punjab.

conversation.input: All right, so in the first part of the exam I'd like to ask you some questions about yourself. Let's talk about the weather. Tell me about the weather in your country.
conversation.output: In general we have quite a mild climate, but perhaps because of global warming it can get quite hot in the summer. We have also had a lot of flooding in parts of the country, which have also increased in recent years.

conversation.input: What kind of weather do you like best?
conversation.output: Honestly speaking, I don't like extreme weather conditions, Rainy weather or really hot, sunny days don't appeal to me at all. I prefer the weather during autumn, it's not too hot and the days also get longer.

conversation.input: What kind of weather do you like when you go on holiday?
conversation.output: To be honest, we usually spend our holidays walking in the countryside, so I prefer mild weather because it's not very enjoyable walking in heavy rain and not too sunny either, as it's easy to get sunburned if you are outside a lot of the day.

conversation.input: Would you prefer to live in a country with a hot or a cold climate?
conversation.output: Actually, I don't really like extreme weather conditions. The climate is quite mild in my country and it never really gets uncomfortable. I'm really not at all keen on hot weather, so I wouldn't like to live anywhere where it gets sweltering hot.

conversation.input: Let's move on to talk about exercise. Do you like to keep fit?
conversation.output: Yes, I take part in a lot of different sports. I play cricket for my college and go swimming once or twice a week. Having said that I'm not fond of going to the gym. I find that a bit boring.

conversation.input: Which sports are popular in your country?
conversation.output: Cricket probably, it's certainly the one that most people talk about and watch on TV, even if they don't play it. However, other things like gymnastics is also very popular and possibly the activity that most people take part in.

conversation.input: Did you do any sports when you were younger that you don't do now?
conversation.output: I used to play basketball when I was at school, but I wasn't very good at it, and I didn't continue with it when I left. We used to do gymnastics as well, and I enjoyed that, but again, I didn't do that once I finisheded school.

conversation.input: Is there a sport that you like to do you had never done before?
conversation.output: You know, I can't swim, but I would love to learn. I have had lessons in the past, but I found it quite difficult. I'm always disappointed when I go on holidays with my friends and can't join them in the swimming pool or in the sea.

conversation.input: Now moving on to the second part of the test. I'm going to give you a topic, and I'd like you to talk about it for one or two minutes before you talk. You have one minute to think about what you are going to say. You can make some notes if you wish. Do you understand.
conversation.output: yes?

conversation.input: Here is your topic. Describe a meal that you like to eat. Remember, you have one or two minutes for this, so don't worry if I stop you. I'll tell you when the time is up. Can you start speaking now, please? Remember, you have one or two minutes for this, so don't worry if I stop you. I'll tell you when the time is up. Can you start speaking now, please?
conversation.output: So food plays an important part in my life, so this is a good question. It's really hard to choose just one meal as there are several things I enjoy eating, but if I had to choose 1, it would be a curry. Perhaps one with chicken from restaurant near where I live, We eat a lot of foreign food at home, for example, Chinese, Italian, Mexican, usually my friends and I will take it in turns to cook and we have curry at least once a week. Honestly speaking, our cooking is okay most of the time, but we have a takeaway on Friday evening as a treat. It's always difficult to decide what to have, but I try to persuade them to order Indian food. In the area where I live, there are a lots of Indian restaurants and I have probably tried all of them, but there's one in particular that makes really nice, nice curryries. There are so many different kinds and it depends on your taste, which one you would like best. What makes Indian food special for me is all the spices used. I usually order a hot curry, a dish with the extra chill in it, The first few mouthfuls burn a bit of course, but you slowly get used to the heat. The food is always beautifully cooked and they often give you something free like small side dishes.

conversation.input: We've been talking about the subject of food, and I'd like to discuss this subject with you with some more general questions relating to this topic. First, what is the appeal of eating out in a restaurant?
conversation.output: I think one reason is that others do all the work, cooking the food, serving it, and washing up afterwards. But also it's exciting to eat out, especially if it's a nice restaurant with the high quality food. Food.

conversation.input: What do you think makes a good dinner host?
conversation.output: Well, let me think. I think the host should be able to cook. It wouldn't be a very nice evening if the meal wasn't tasty. I think it's important that a host makes you feel comfortable as well, and they should also be good at keeping the conversations going to encourage everyone to have a good time.

conversation.input: Fast food is often criticised by food experts, so why is it so popular with people?
conversation.output: Probably because it's quick and convenient if you have had a busy day at work or have been studying all day long, you might not want to spend time cooking. In some places you can just drive in order your food, pay and drive home. So it's very easy.

conversation.input: Do you think it's always best to eat food with ingredients that have been produced locally?
conversation.output: You know, I think it's good for the environment, it means food isn't being transported around the country or even around the world, It's obviously also good for the local economy if food is bought from farmers and other food producers in the area.

conversation.input: Is it important to eat together at the dinner table rather than in front of the TV, for example?
conversation.output: My parents always made me and my sister eat at the table at mealtimes. We weren't allowed to have our mobile phones with us when we were eating. So yeah, in my opinion, this was a good idea as it meant we were able to talk to each other and find out what was going on in our lives at the time.

conversation.input: How can we best encourage people to eat a healthy diet?
conversation.output: To be honest, I think you need to start by educating children so that they get into good habits. It's a good idea to encourage them to help prepare food. I think there's more chance they'll eat things they normally wouldn't like if they are involved more in cooking.

conversation.input: That is the end of the speaking test. Thank you.
conversation.output: Thank you.

conversation.output: So the question was, if I could describe something that I enjoyed making as a child and the first thing that came to mind was I used to make Christmas, Christmas cards with my mom. And I really enjoy doing that because it was a tradition and I did it with my mom. So we, started in November and we started making Christmas carts for all the friends and acquaintances that sent us a cart the year before. They didn't send us a cart the year before, we usually didn't send them one back. And it was quite difficult in the beginning because it's very nitty gritty, small work, but, it got better as I got older. And I think we kept doing it until I was about 13 years old. And the best reason for doing it was really just to spend time with my mom with Christmas music in the back. And, it was always fun seeing the new kinds of cars that they brought out that year. So it was usually, it was some kind of animals, some kind of birds or or puppies or whatever. And it was a lot of fun actually just spending some quality time together and having Christmas juices gonna back and cake in the oven and just spending a few hours doing something that was just ours. Really.
